questions.question: Question 1: The maximum contractile force of any muscle per square cm cross-sectional area is
questions.explanation:
The strength of a muscle is determined mainly by its size, with a maximal contractile force 
between 3 and 4 kg/cm2 of muscle cross-sectional area. 809 
Sold by @itachibot • The female muscle can achieve almost exactly the same maximal force of contraction as that of 
the male muscle per square centimeter of cross-sectional area. • Most of the difference in total muscle performance between males and females lies in the extra 
percentage of the male body that is muscle, which is caused partly by endocrine differences: • Testosterone secreted by the male testes has a powerful anabolic effect in causing greatly 
increased deposition of protein in the muscles. • Estrogen increases the deposition of fat in the female, especially in the breasts, hips, and 
subcutaneous tissue.

questions.question:
Question 2: A budding athlete who is keen to participate in long races visits his dietician for a discussion 
on his exercise capacity. When an athlete runs at a speed typical for the marathon race, the 
time until complete exhaustion is maximal with which of the following diets?
questions.explanation:
When athletes run at speeds typical for the marathon race, the time that they can sustain the 
race until complete exhaustion (also known as endurance) is maximal with a high-carbohydrate 
diet. A person, who consumes a high-carbohydrate diet, stores far more glycogen in muscles than does 
a person who consumes either a mixed diet or a high-fat diet. Therefore, endurance is enhanced 
by a high-carbohydrate diet. When athletes run at speeds typical for the marathon race, their endurance is approximately the 
following: Diet 
Minu 
tes 240 High-carbohydrate di 
et Mixed diet 
120 High-fat diet 
85

questions.question:
Question 3: A professional athlete uses phosphocreatine to improve his sprinting capacity and maximize 
muscle power during a 100 m dash race. Which of the following energy systems is utilized by 
the muscles of the athlete's body during a dash race?
questions.explanation:
The phosphagen system is utilized by the muscles of the athlete's body during a dash race. The combined amounts of cell ATP and cell phosphocreatine are called the phosphagen energy 
system. These substances together can provide maximal muscle power for 8 to 10 seconds, almost 
enough for the 100-meter run. Thus, the energy from the phosphagen system is used for maximal 
short bursts of muscle power. Energy systems: • The phosphocreatine-creatine system: The combined amounts of cell ATP and cell 
phosphocreatine are called the phosphagen energy system. These substances together can provide 
maximal muscle power for 8 to 10 seconds. • The glycogen–lactic acid system: can provide 1.3 to 1.6 minutes of maximal muscle activity. 810 
Sold by @itachibot • The aerobic system: The aerobic system is the oxidation of foodstuffs in the mitochondria to 
provide energy. It can sustain mucle activity for an unlimited time (as long as nutrients last).

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following is false regarding muscles adapted for endurance running? 805 
Sold by @itachibot

options.d: Twice as large in diameter compared to fast twitch fibers

questions.explanation:
Slow-twitch fibres, which are adapted for endurance running, are not larger in diameter than 
fast-twitch fibres. Fast-twitch fibres are about twice as large in diameter compared with 
slow-twitch fibres. Fast-Twitch and Slow-Twitch Muscle Fibers • Fast-twitch fibres can deliver extreme amounts of power from a few seconds to a minute. • The enzymes that promote rapid release of energy from the phosphagen and glycogen–lactic acid 
energy systems are more active in fast-twitch fibres. • Fast-twitch fibres are about twice as large in diameter compared with slow-twitch fibres. • Gastrocnemius muscle has a higher preponderance of fast-twitch fibres, which gives it the 
capability of forceful and rapid contraction of the type used in jumping. • Slow-twitch fibres are mainly organized for endurance, especially for the generation of aerobic 
energy. • They have far more mitochondria than do the fast-twitch fibres. • They contain considerably more myoglobin. The extra myoglobin increases the rate of diffusion 
of oxygen throughout the fibre. • The enzymes of the aerobic metabolic system are considerably more active in slow-twitch fibres. • The number of capillaries is greater in the vicinity of slow-twitch fibres. • Soleus muscle has a higher preponderance of slow-twitch muscle fibres and therefore is used to a 
greater extent for prolonged lower leg muscle activity.

questions.question:
Question 5: Regarding respiratory adjustment seen during exercise, which of the following statements is 
true?

options.a: Activity of joint proprioceptors is important factor in increasing ventilation
options.c: Arterio-venous difference in oxygen concentration remains constant

questions.explanation:
Signals from joint proprioceptors play a role in stimulating the respiratory drive during exercise. Regulation of respiration in exercise • During strenuous exercise, O2 consumption and CO2 for mation can increase as much as 20- 
fold. Yet in the healthy athlete, the arterial PO2, PCO2, and pH remain almost exactly 
normal. This is because the alveolar ventilation increases along with the increased level of oxygen 
metabolism. • Part of this stimulation of alveolar ventilation results from direct stimulation of the respiratory 
center by nervous signals. An additional part is believed to result from sensory signals transmitted 
into the respiratory center from the contracting muscles and joint proprioceptors. • During strenuous exercise, the utilization of O2 in the entire body can increase to 75% to 85%. 
So, essentially all the oxygen is given to the exercising muscles leading to an increased 811 
Sold by @itachibot arterio-venous difference in oxygen concentration.

questions.question: Question 6: Exercise at high altitudes is not hindered by which of the following factors?

options.b: Fall in the total oxygen supply available

questions.explanation:
The fall in blood bicarbonate levels is compensatory, and it helps increase the exercise effort, not 
hinder it. Adaptation at High Altitudes The work capacity is reduced at high altitudes and this reduction is in direct proportion to the 
decrease in O2 uptake. (Option B) Immediate exposure to low PO2 at higher altitudes stimulates the arterial chemoreceptors, and 
this stimulation increases alveolar ventilation. This immediate increase in pulmonary ventilation upon rising to a high altitude blows off large 
quantities of CO2, reducing the PCO2 and increasing the pH of the body fluids (Respiratory 
alkalosis). This raised pH inhibits the brain stem respiratory center and opposes the increased 
ventilation. So, respiratory alkalosis will hinder the maximal exercise effort. (Option C). To compensate for this respiratory alkalosis, kidneys reduce hydrogen ion secretion and increase 
bicarbonate excretion. This reduces plasma and cerebrospinal fluid bicarbonate concentration and 
brings the pH towards normal. This removes the inhibitory effect of alkalosis on respiration. 
Hence the fall in blood bicarbonate facilitates the exercise effort. NOTE Lactic acid causes extreme fatigue. (Option D) Ordinarily, the pyruvic acid from glycolysis enters the mitochondria of muscle cells and reacts 
with oxygen to form many ATP molecules. However, when there is insufficient oxygen (at high altitudes), most of the pyruvic acid then is 
converted into lactic acid, which diffuses out of the muscle cells into the interstitial fluid and 
blood. 812 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: A 30-year-old man who is extremely motivated to participate in high-intensity exercises is 
advised to quit smoking by this physician. Which of the following is not a reason behind 
smoking-related decrease in exercise capacity?

options.b: Increased fluid secretion into the bronchial tree
options.c: Paralysis of cilia on the surfaces of the respiratory epithelial cells

questions.explanation:
Smoking causes no change to the sensitivity of the chemoreceptors. Effect of Smoking on Pulmonary Ventilation in Exercise • Nicotine causes constriction of the terminal bronchioles of the lungs, which increases the 
resistance of air flow into and out of the lungs. • The irritating effects of the smoke causes increased fluid secretion into the bronchial tree and 
some degree of swelling of the epithelial linings, which again increases airflow resistance. • Nicotine paralyzes the cilia on the surfaces of the respiratory epithelial cells. As a result, much 
debris accumulates in the passageways, and this adds further to the difficulty in breathing. • All these factors together make even a light smoker experience respiratory strain during maximal 
exercise, and their level of performance may be reduced. • In persons with severe emphysema, as much as four-fifths of the respiratory membrane can be 
destroyed; then, even the slightest exercise can cause respiratory distress. Chronic smoking is an 
important cause of emphysema.

questions.question:
Question 8: 806 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is seen in response to exercise?

options.a: Increased cerebral blood flow due to increase in systolic blood pressure
options.c: Increased blood flow in muscles after at least 15 minutes of activity

questions.explanation:
Exercise causes an increase in body temperature. Almost all the energy released by the body’s metabolism of nutrients is eventually converted into 
body heat. Since metabolism rises significantly during exercise there is an increase in the body 
temperature. This increase in body temperature is significant and even lethal conditions such as 
heatstroke can easily develop in an athlete. Other options: Option A: Cerebral blood flow is “autoregulated” extremely well between arterial pressure limits of 
60 and 140 mm Hg. That is, the mean arterial pressure can be increased to as high as 140 mm Hg 
without significant change in cerebral blood flow. Option B: The arterial Po2, Pco2, and pH remain almost exactly normal even though during 
strenuous exercise, O2 consumption and CO2 formation can increase as much as 20 fold. Option C: The increase in blood flow to exercising muscles is immediate and not after 15 minutes.

questions.question:
Question 9: Which of the following circulatory systems demonstrates an increase in blood supply during 
exercise?
questions.explanation:
Coronary circulation increases during exercise. During exercise, blood flow • Decreases in inactive skeletal muscles, kidney, liver, and GIT 813 
Sold by @itachibot • Remains unaltered in brain (due to autoregulation) • Increases in exercising muscles, coronary circulation • Initially decreases due to redistribution, but later increases due to an increase in temperature in 
the skin

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is not true regarding exercise-induced physiological changes?

options.a: Left shift of Hb-O2 dissociation curve
options.b: Increase in blood supply to muscle

questions.explanation:
Left shift of Hb-O2 dissociation curve is not seen during exercise. During exercise, several factors shift the Hb-O2 dissociation curve considerably to the right, thus 
delivering extra amounts of O2 to the active, exercising muscle fibers. The right shift of Hb-O2 dissociation curve is due to the following: • Release of large quantities of CO2 by the exercising muscles • Increase in the hydrogen ion concentration in the muscle capillary blood • Increase in the temperature of the muscle by 2° to 3°C

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following is the main cause of increased blood flow to exercising muscles ?

options.c: Increased sympathetic discharge to peripheral vessels

questions.explanation:
The tremendous increase in muscle blood flow that occurs during skeletal muscle activity is 
caused mainly by chemicals acting directly on the muscle arterioles to cause dilation. These chemicals include: • Potassium ions, • Adenosine triphosphate (ATP), • Lactic acid, and • Carbon dioxide. Other factors leading to increased muscle flow include • sympathetic nervous system activation • increase in arterial pressure, and • increase in cardiac output. However, the effect of local metabolites is greater than these factors in increasing the muscle 
blood flow. Hence, the best answer is local metabolites.

questions.question:
Question 12: 807 
Sold by @itachibot Isometric (static) exercise differs from isotonic (dynamic) exercise in that it causes a greater 
increase in  
.
questions.explanation:
There is a sharp rise in the diastolic blood pressure in isometric exercise. This is due to the 
sustained compression of the blood vessels by the contracting muscles. In isotonic exercise, there 814 
Sold by @itachibot is much vasodilatation in exercising muscles. So, even though the muscles are contracting, there is 
no rise in the diastolic blood pressure. Option (a) Since the muscle pump is more active during isotonic exercise, the venous return is 
higher in isotonic exercise. Option (b) The increase in the muscle blood flow is less compared to isotonic exercise since inflow 
of blood is obstructed by sustained compression exerted by the contracting muscle. Option (d) Isometric exercise increases the after load of the heart leading to less increase in the 
stroke volume of the heart.

questions.question:
Question 13: Regarding circulatory adjustments made during exercise,  
.

options.a: The cardiac output increases more than ten-fold.
options.b: Increase in cardiac output is mainly due to an increase in stroke volume.
options.c: The mean systemic filling pressure rises at the onset of heavy exercise.
options.d: In severe exercise, the systolic blood pressure falls.

questions.explanation:
The mean systemic filling pressure rises tremendously at the onset of heavy exercise. This occurs as a result of • The sympathetic stimulation contracts the veins. • Tensing of the abdominal and other skeletal muscles of the body compresses many of the 
internal vessels, thus providing more compression of the entire vascular system and causing a still 
greater increase in mean systemic filling pressure. Cardiovascular Changes in Exercise • The maximum increase of cardiac output is 4-fold that can commonly be achieved by the 
untrained runner and 7-fold that can be achieved in some marathon runners. • The increase in heart rate accounts for a greater proportion of the increase in cardiac output 
than the increase in stroke volume during sustained strenuous exercise. • Exercise also causes an increased venous return due to • Increased activity of the respiratory pump • Increased activity of the muscular pump • Increased venous tone due to sympathetic stimulation • Increased blood flow from arteries to veins • In severe exercise, there is increased systolic and mean blood pressure due to • vasoconstriction of the arterioles and small arteries in most tissues of the body • increased pumping activity by the heart • a great increase in mean systemic filling pressure caused mainly by venous contraction. 815 
Sold by @itachibot • As seen in the figure, point A is the resting cardiac output. On exercise, there is a rise in the 
mean systemic filling pressure shown on the X-axis. • The venous return also rises which causes the cardiac output to reach point B, which is 4 times 
the normal resting cardiac output.

questions.question:
Question 14: Which of the following is not true regarding the increase in the blood supply of muscles 
during exercise?
questions.explanation:
During exercise, there is increased beta-adrenergic stimulation. Medullae of the two adrenal glands secrete large amounts of norepinephrine plus epinephrine into 
the circulating blood during strenuous exercise. The epinephrine often has a slight vasodilator 
effect because it excites more of the beta-adrenergic receptors of the vessels, which are vasodilator 
receptors, in contrast to the alpha vasoconstrictor receptors excited especially by norepinephrine. 816 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is not seen in strenuous exercise?

options.d: Right shift of O2-Hb dissociation curve

questions.explanation: Strenuous exercise can cause hyperkalemia by releasing potassium from skeletal muscle. NOTE: Exercise leads to release of endogenous opiods and is associated with mood enhancement.

questions.question:
Question 16: 808 
Sold by @itachibot Calculate the respiratory quotient (R•) in a patient with 50kg body weight, if the CO2 exhaled 
is 200ml/min and O2 consumed is 250 ml/min.
questions.explanation:
The respiratory quotient is 0.8. The respiratory quotient is the ratio of carbon dioxide production to oxygen utilization. In the given question, the CO2 production is 200mL/min, while the O2 consumption is 
250mL/min. Therefore, Respiratory quotient = 200/250 = 0.8 The respiratory quotient (R•) is used for determining the metabolic utilization of various foods. • When carbohydrates are metabolized with one molecule of oxygen, one carbon dioxide molecule 
is released. Therefore, the R• of carbohydrates = 1. • When fats are oxidized, for every 100 molecules of oxygen consumed, 70 molecules of CO2 are 
released. Therefore, the R• of fats is 0.70. • Similarly, the respiratory quotient for proteins is 0.80. 817 
Sold by @itachibot
